title: Coline Campbell
text:
Coline M. Campbell (born 26 September 1940) is a former member of the <a href="House%20of%20Commons%20of%20Canada">House of Commons of Canada</a> in the <a href="30th%20Canadian%20Parliament">30th (1974–1979)</a>, <a href="32nd%20Canadian%20Parliament">32nd (1980–1984)</a> and <a href="34th%20Canadian%20Parliament">34th (1988–1993) Canadian Parliaments</a>. Campbell was the first woman from Nova Scotia elected to the House of Commons.
Before politics.
Prior to entering politics, Campbell was a teacher and lawyer.
Political career.
Campbell was first elected in the <a href="1974%20Canadian%20federal%20election">1974 federal election</a> at the <a href="West%20Nova">South Western Nova</a> <a href="Electoral%20district%20%28Canada%29">electoral district</a> for the <a href="Liberal%20Party%20of%20Canada">Liberal Party</a>. She served as a backbench supporter of <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Canada">Prime Minister</a> <a href="Pierre%20Trudeau">Pierre Trudeau</a>'s government. After her first term in Parliament, she was defeated by <a href="Charles%20E.%20Haliburton">Charles E. Haliburton</a> of the <a href="Progressive%20Conservative%20Party%20of%20Canada">Progressive Conservative (PC) Party</a> in the <a href="1979%20Canadian%20federal%20election">1979 federal election</a>; following electoral redistribution in 1976, her riding had been renamed South West Nova.
Following the short-lived Progressive Conservative minority government of <a href="Joe%20Clark">Joe Clark</a>, she was re-elected at South West Nova in <a href="1980%20Canadian%20federal%20election">1980</a>. She served as a government-side backbencher under Pierre Trudeau and <a href="John%20Turner">John Turner</a> until the <a href="1984%20Canadian%20federal%20election">1984 Canadian federal election</a>, when she lost the seat again to PC challenger <a href="Gerald%20Comeau">Gerald Comeau</a>.
Her last term in Parliament began with her second comeback in the <a href="1988%20Canadian%20federal%20election">1988 federal election</a>. She served in opposition under John Turner and <a href="Jean%20Chr%C3%A9tien">Jean Chrétien</a>. She did not seek another term in Parliament after this and left federal politics as of the <a href="1993%20Canadian%20federal%20election">1993 federal election</a>.
